{{Infobox officeholder | name = Seyyed Abdul-Karim Mousavi Ardebili | image = File:Abdul-Karim Mousavi Ardebili (5).jpg | caption = Grand Ayatollah Mousavi Ardebili | birth_date = {{birth date|1926|1|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Ardabil]], [[Imperial State of Iran|Iran]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|11|23|1926|1|28|df=y}} | death_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | order = [[Chief Justice of Iran]]
Head of [[Supreme Court of Iran]] |appointer = [[Ruhollah Khomeini]] | term_start = 28 June 1981 | term_end = 30 June 1989 | predecessor = [[Mohammad Beheshti]] | successor = [[Mohammad Yazdi]] | order1 = [[Attorney-General of Iran]] | term_start1 = 1 June 1980 | term_end1 = 28 June 1981 | appointer1= [[Mohammad Beheshti]] | predecessor1 = Mohammad Mehdi Amlashi | successor1 = [[Hossein Mousavi Tabrizi]] | order2= [[Assembly of Experts|Member of the Assembly of Experts]] | term_start2= 15 August 1983 | term_end2 = 1 December 1991 | constituency2 = [[Tehran Province]] | party = [[Assembly of Qom Seminary Scholars and Researchers]] | otherparty = [[Islamic Republican Party]] | alma_mater = [[Qom Seminary]] | occupation = | religion = [[Shia Islam]] | nationality = [[Iran]]ian | website = [http://www.ardebili.com/FA/Home/Index/ Official website] }} '''Seyyed Abdul-Karim Mousavi Ardebili''' ({{lang-fa|عبدالکریم موسوی اردبیلی}}, 28 January 1926 – 23 November 2016) was an Iranian [[Iranian Reformists|reformist]] politician and [[Twelver]] [[shi'a]] [[Marja'|marja]]. ==Political career== Ardebili was a supporter of Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini]] and was a friend of his. He made speeches in support of Khomeini in the 1970s. After the [[Iranian Revolution]], he became a founding member of [[Islamic Republican Party|the Islamic Republican party]] that was founded in 1979.{{cite journal|last=Asayesh|first=Hossein|author2=Adlina Ab. Halim|author3=Jayum A. Jawan |author4=Seyedeh Nosrat Shojaei|title=Political Party in Islamic Republic of Iran: A Review|journal=Journal of Politics and Law|date=March 2011|volume=4|issue=1|url=http://www.ccsenet.org/journal/index.php/jpl/article/view/9606/6898|accessdate=29 July 2013}} Khomeini appointed him as [[Judicial system of Iran|chief of justice]] in 1981 after the impeachment of President [[Abulhassan Banisadr]]. As chief justice, he served as member of the temporary council of the Presidency, along with the [[Prime Minister of Iran|Prime Minister]] and [[List of Speakers of the Parliament of Iran|Speaker]], carrying out the duties of the president for up to two months.{{cite journal |last=Ramazani |first=Rouhollah K. |date=Spring 1980 |title=Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran |jstor=4326018 |journal=Middle East Journal |publisher=Middle East Institute |volume=34 |issue=2 |pages=181–204 |doi= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,924070-2,00.html Is the Ayatullah a Heretic?], ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', Monday, 28 April 1980 {{s-start}} {{s-legal}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mohammad Beheshti]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Head of [[Judiciary System of Iran]]|years=1981–1989}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mohammad Yazdi]]}} {{s-end}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mousavi Ardebili, Abdolkarim}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Iranian Azerbaijani grand ayatollahs and clerics]] [[Category:Iranian politicians]] [[Category:Iranian heads of Judicial System]] [[Category:People from Ardabil]] [[Category:Chief Justices of Iran]] [[Category:Al-Moussawi family]] [[Category:People of the Iranian Revolution]] [[Category:Iranian Azerbaijani politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Assembly of Experts]] [[Category:Islamic Republican Party politicians]] [[Category:Council of the Islamic Revolution members]] [[Category:Members of the Assembly of Experts for Constitution]]

revision.text:
'''Adam Garnet Jones''' is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] filmmaker and screenwriter.<ref name=edmonton>"Young, native and gay, filmmaker champions inclusion for all". ''[[Edmonton Journal]]'', March 24, 2007.</ref>
Of [[Cree]] and [[Métis]] ancestry,<ref name=edmonton /> Jones grew up in [[Alberta]] and [[British Columbia]].<ref name=young>"Young filmmaker knows his subject matter well". ''[[Toronto Star]]'', September 14, 2006.</ref> Battling [[suicide|suicidal]] impulses in his early teens as he came to terms with being [[gay]],<ref name=young/> he recovered a sense of purpose by making short films and videos and attending the [[Gulf Islands Film and Television School]],<ref name=young/> and subsequently moved to [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] to study film at [[Ryerson University]].<ref name=young/> After graduating from Ryerson, his short film ''Cloudbreaker'' premiered at the [[2006 Toronto International Film Festival]],<ref name=young /> and he coordinated a youth film and video program for Toronto's [[Inside Out Film and Video Festival]].<ref>"Coming out on film; Young gays share what it's like 'They aren't sure where they fit in'". ''[[Toronto Star]]'', May 19, 2006.</ref>
He subsequently made the short films ''A Small Thing'', ''Wave a Red Flag'' and ''Liar'', wrote an episode of the television series ''Cashing In'', and was a writer and story editor on the television series ''[[Mohawk Girls (TV series)|Mohawk Girls]]''.<ref>[http://urbannativemag.com/adam-garnet-jones-prepares-to-make-first-feature-length-film/ "Adam Garnet Jones prepares to make first feature-length film"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303021852/http://urbannativemag.com/adam-garnet-jones-prepares-to-make-first-feature-length-film/ |date=2016-03-03 }}. ''Urban Native'', July 10, 2014.</ref>
His feature film debut, ''[[Fire Song]]'', premiered at the [[2015 Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/toronto-canadian-film-lineup-showcases-813283 "Toronto: Canadian Film Lineup Showcases Hollywood, Foreign Stars"]. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', August 5, 2015.</ref> ''Fire Song'' went on to pick up Audience Choice awards at four film festivals, including the [[imagineNATIVE Film + Media Arts Festival]].
Jones' second film, ''[[Great Great Great]]'', premiered at the [[Canadian Filmmakers' Festival]] in March 2017, where it won three of the festival's top awards for Best Feature, Best Screenplay and Best Performance. ''Great Great Great'' was released theatrically that same year.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2017/03/17/canadian-film-fest-opens-for-patriotic-moviegoers-projections.html "Canadian Film Fest opens for patriotic moviegoers: Projections"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', March 17, 2017.</ref> At the [[6th Canadian Screen Awards]] in 2018, Jones and [[Sarah Kolasky]] received a nomination for [[Academy of Canadian Cinema and Television Award for Best Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]].<ref>[https://nowtoronto.com/movies/features/the-canadian-screen-awards-2018-nominations/ "The Canadian Screen Awards showers love on (almost) everyone"]. ''[[Now (newspaper)|Now]]'', January 16, 2018.</ref>
In 2018 he published his first [[young adult novel]], an adaptation of ''Fire Song''.<ref>[https://quillandquire.com/authors/adam-garnet-jones-adapts-his-award-winning-film-into-a-ya-novel-with-universal-appeal/ "Adam Garnet Jones adapts his award-winning film into a YA novel with universal appeal"]. ''[[Quill & Quire]]'', March 2018.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|2049672}} *{{official website|http://www.adamgarnetjones.com}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jones, Adam Garnet}} [[Category:Film directors from Alberta]] [[Category:Canadian television writers]] [[Category:First Nations filmmakers]] [[Category:LGBT writers from Canada]] [[Category:LGBT directors]] [[Category:LGBT screenwriters]] [[Category:LGBT First Nations people]] [[Category:Gay writers]] [[Category:Cree people]] [[Category:Writers from Alberta]] [[Category:Writers from British Columbia]] [[Category:Ryerson University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:First Nations screenwriters]] [[Category:21st-century Canadian novelists]] [[Category:Canadian male novelists]] [[Category:Canadian writers of young adult literature]] [[Category:First Nations novelists]] [[Category:LGBT novelists]] [[Category:Film directors from British Columbia]] [[Category:21st-century First Nations writers]] [[Category:Canadian male screenwriters]] [[Category:21st-century Canadian screenwriters]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Adame Ba Konaré | image = | alt = | caption = | office = [[First Lady of Mali]] | term_start = March 26, 1999 | term_end = June 8, 2002 | predecessor = [[Touré Lobbo Traoré]] | successor = [[Touré Lobbo Traoré]] | president = [[Alpha Oumar Konaré]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|09|22}} | birth_place = [[Ségou, Mali]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Mali]]an | spouse = {{marriage|Alpha Oumar Konaré|15 September 1971}} | occupation = [[Historian]] | known_for = }} '''Adame Ba Konaré''' (born 1 May 1947 in [[Ségou|Segu]], [[Mali]]) is a Malian historian<ref>{{cite book|last=Chretien|first=Jean-Pierre|title=L'Afrique de Sarkozy Un deni de l'histoire|year=2008|publisher=Karthala|isbn=978-2-8111-0004-9|pages=11–13|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=cIWqGZ01bCcC&oi=fnd&pg=PA7&dq=Reponse+de+Adame+Ba+Konare+a+Sarkozy&ots=_dg-grRS9j&sig=qfX8E-UHwMqkzDGxrOYsfYJoUSs#v=onepage&q=Adame%20Ba%20Konare&f=false}}</ref> and writer who is married to [[Alpha Oumar Konaré]], former [[Heads of State of Mali|President of Mali]].<ref name="article">{{cite web|last=Dougueli|first=Georges|title=Adame Ba Konare|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/LIN30097adameranoka0/|publisher=Jeune Afrique|accessdate=9 March 2013}}</ref> She is active in several causes for newborns and refugees.
==Life== Adame Ba Konaré was born in [[Ségou]] on 1 May 1947 to Marmadou Ba who was a dentist and his wife Kadiatou Thiam. Her parents hailed from a [[Fula people|Fula]] family. She attended the highest education facility, the [[École Normale Supérieure]] in [[Bamako]], along with her future husband, Alpha Oumar Konaré. They married on 15 September 1971. Her new husband was employed as a high school teacher but he was to be sent to the [[University of Warsaw]] to undertake doctoral research. They both obtained a PhD in History in 1976. She returned to Mali and became a history professor at her alma mata in Bamako.<ref name=akyearn/>
Konaré and her spouse worked together on several projects. They published a book together in 1983 called ''Grande Dates Du Mali'' and they both worked for the democratic cause under the presidency of Moussa Traore who ruled Mali's single party state until 1991. During that time they created a publishing house ''Jamana'' and a daily newspaper ''Les Echos'' and a political party called ADEMA-PAS. In 1991 the president was deposed and in the following elections her husband was democratically elected.<ref name=akyearn/>
Konaré has written various types of books, from biographies (about [[Sunni Ali Ber]]) to philosophy (''L'Os de la parole'') and even a novel (''Quand l'ail se frotte a l'encens''), the plot of which focuses on the social gap in a fictional society similar to Mali's. For this book, her style has been compared to French authors [[Emile Zola]] and [[Victor Hugo]]'s works.
Although officially retired, she is often invited to conferences on African History. In addition to her work in academia, Adam Ba Konare is also an outspoken feminist, and the founder of one of the few women's museums in [[Africa]].<ref name=akyearn>{{cite book|last=Akyeampong|first=Emmanuel K.|title=Dictionary of African biography|date=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0195382072|pages=419–420|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0195382072|editor=chief, Henry Louis Gates Jr. editors in}}</ref> The museum was started in 1987 following the publication of Konaré's book ''The Dictionary of Famous Women of Mali''. The museum, [[Muso Kunda]], is funded by Konaré.<ref>[http://www.museedelafemme.com/historique.html History and Mission] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025022854/http://www.museedelafemme.com/historique.html |date=October 25, 2013 }}, Muso Kunda, retrieved 11 March 2014</ref>
More recently, she has been involved in a project to promote African History, following French president [[Nicolas Sarkozy]]'s speech in [[Dakar]].<ref name="article" /> The movement aims to write a history of Africa, defending the African legacy and past civilizations. As an historian, Adam Ba Konare disagreed with Sarkozy's speech and invited African historians, intellectuals and all friends of Africa to join to write a rebuttal to Sarkozy's speech in order to denounce "the attacks on African memory".<ref name="article"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://google.com/search?q=cache:INMSMC4yoOgJ:www.africa-union.org/News_Events/Press_Releases/15%252004%2520Konare%2520brings%2520AU%2520to%2520grassroots%2520peole%2520in%2520AA.pdf+%22Adame+Ba+Konar%C3%A9%22+-list+-liste+-Wikipedia&hl=en African Union article]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110927075316/http://www.r-e-t.com/council.php Refugee Education trust] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070212081302/http://www.museedelafemme.com/ Site of the Women's Museum (Muso Kunda)] * [http://aflit.arts.uwa.edu.au/BaKonareAdameEng.html Adame Ba Konaré, University of Western Australia]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Konare, Adame Ba}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:First Ladies of Mali]] [[Category:Malian historians]] [[Category:Malian women novelists]] [[Category:Fula people]] [[Category:People from Ségou]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Use British English|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Andy Hunt | image = | caption = | fullname = Andrew Hunt | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1970|6|9}} | birth_place = [[West Thurrock]], England | height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}} | currentclub = | clubnumber = | position = [[Striker (association football)|Striker]] | years1 = 1990–1991 | years2 = 1991–1993 | years3 = 1993 | years4 = 1993–1998 | years5 = 1998–2000 | clubs1 = [[Kettering Town F.C.|Kettering Town]] | clubs2 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | clubs3 = → [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] (loan) | clubs4 = [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] | clubs5 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] | caps1 = 0 | caps2 = 43 | caps3 = 9 | caps4 = 202 | caps5 = 86 | totalcaps = 341 | goals1 = 0 | goals2 = 11 | goals3 = 9 | goals4 = 67 | goals5 = 35 | totalgoals = 124 }} '''Andrew Hunt''' (born 9 June 1970 in [[West Thurrock]], [[Essex]]) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]].
==Career==
Hunt started his career in [[non-league football]], whilst training in business and tourism management, with [[King's Lynn F.C.|King's Lynn]] and [[Kettering Town F.C.|Kettering Town]] before being signed by then manager [[Jim Smith (footballer)|Jim Smith]] for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in early 1991. Smith departed soon after, and Hunt continued to play under his successor [[Ossie Ardiles]].
However, this was not a successful time for the Magpies, who had fallen into the Second Division in 1989 and failed to make even the playoffs in the [[1990-91 in English football|1990-91 season]]. Ardiles reshaped the side for the [[1991-92 in English football|1991-92 season]] by drafting in more young players and adopting a very attacking style of football, but things failed to improve and by the end of October in 1991 the Magpies were bottom of the Second Division.
Ardiles was sacked on 5 February 1992 and replaced by [[Kevin Keegan]], who chose [[David Kelly (association footballer)|David Kelly]] and [[Micky Quinn]] as his first choice attacking force. Hunt was on the sidelines for much of the next 12 months before departing to [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], where Ardiles was now the manager. Hunt scored a hat-trick on his home debut for Albion in March 1993 against Brighton.<ref>{{cite book | last = Matthews | first = Tony | title = The Who's Who of West Bromwich Albion | publisher = Breedon Books | year = 2005 | pages = 120–121 | isbn = 1-85983-474-4}}</ref> He scored the first goal in the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] play-off final in 1993 at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]] as West Brom beat [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] 3–0 to gain promotion.
Hunt was a regular over the next five seasons, creating an effective partnership with [[Bob Taylor (footballer)|Bob Taylor]], but West Brom failed to gain another promotion. In 1998, he joined [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], who had just been promoted to the [[Premier League]], on a free transfer. Charlton were relegated in Hunt's first season with them, but in his second season Hunt scored twenty four goals as Charlton won [[Football League First Division|Division One]] to win promotion back to the Premiership. However, he retired early from football during the [[2000-01 in English football|2000–01]] season due to [[chronic fatigue syndrome]]. Hunt returned to Charlton briefly in 2003 to try to earn another contract, and played in three reserve games, but was not offered a contract.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
Hunt now runs the Belize Jungle Dome and Green Dragon Adventure Travel, a pair of [[adventure travel]] companies in [[Belize]], with his wife, former [[MTV]] presenter [[Simone Angel]]. Hunt also maintains a [[blog]] which details how he became a professional footballer, and his thoughts on different football issues.{{cn|date=October 2018}}
==Honours==
===As a Player===
====Promotions==== *[[1992-93 in English football|1992–93]]: [[Football League Division Two|Division Two]] Playoff Winner (promotion to [[Football League Division One|Division One]]) - [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] *[[1999-00 in English football|1999–00]]: [[Football League Division One|Division One]] Champion (promotion to [[Premier League|The Premiership]]) - [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Soccerbase}} *[http://www.greendragonbelize.com/ Green Dragon Adventure Travel] *[http://www.belizejungledome.com/ Belize Jungle Dome] *[http://escribbler.blogspot.com/ Hunt's personal blog]
