convocation|url=http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/radan_gs09/d_ank_arh?kod=212303|website=Official portal|publisher=[[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]|accessdate=22 December 2014|language=Ukrainian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405083801/http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/radan_gs09/d_ank_arh?kod=212303|archivedate=5 April 2015|df=dmy-all}} | term_start4 = 12 May 1998 | term_end4 = 14 May 2002 | convocation5 = [[4th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|4th convocation]] | constituency5 = [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine Bloc]], [[Vinnytsia Oblast]], [[Vinnytsia II (single-mandate constituency)|District No.12]]{{cite web|title=People's Deputy of Ukraine of the IV convocation|url=http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/2273/5|website=Official portal|publisher=[[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]|accessdate=22 December 2014|language=Ukrainian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113164921/http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/2273/5|archivedate=13 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Registered candidates|url=http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vd2002/WEBPROC0V|website=Elections of the People's Deputies of Ukraine|publisher=[[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]|accessdate=24 December 2014|language=Ukrainian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101083540/http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vd2002/WEBPROC0V|archivedate=1 January 2015|df=dmy-all}} | term_start5 = 14 May 2003 | term_end5 = 8 September 2006 | convocation6 = [[5th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|5th convocation]] | constituency6 = [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine Bloc]], No.33{{cite web|title=People's Deputy of Ukraine of the V convocation|url=http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/2273/6|website=Official portal|publisher=[[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]|accessdate=22 December 2014|language=Ukrainian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150608060139/http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/2273/6|archivedate=8 June 2015|df=dmy-all}} | term_start6 = 25 May 2006 | term_end6 = 15 June 2007 | convocation7 = [[7th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|7th convocation]] | constituency7 = [[Independent (politician)|Independent]], [[Vinnytsia Oblast]],
[[Vinnytsia II (single-mandate constituency)|District No.12]]{{cite web|title=People's Deputy of Ukraine of the VII convocation|url=http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/2273/8|website=Official portal|publisher=[[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]|accessdate=22 December 2014|language=Ukrainian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113164920/http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/expage/2273/8|archivedate=13 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} | term_start7 = 12 December 2012 | term_end7 = 3 June 2014 }} '''Petro Oleksiyovych Poroshenko''' ({{lang-uk|Петро́ Олексі́йович Пороше́нко}}, {{IPA-uk|pɛˈtrɔ ɔlɛkˈsʲijɔwɪtʃ pɔrɔˈʃɛnkɔ|pron}}; born 26 September 1965{{cite web |url=http://www.president.gov.ua/en/president/petro-poroshenko |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210185957/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/president/petro-poroshenko |archivedate=10 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }}) is the fifth and current [[President of Ukraine|President]] of [[Ukraine]] (excluding acting president [[Oleksandr Turchynov]]), in office since 2014. He served as the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Ukraine)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] from 2009 to 2010, and as the [[Ministry of Economic Development and Trade (Ukraine)|Minister of Trade and Economic Development]] in 2012. From 2007 until 2012, Poroshenko headed the Council of [[National Bank of Ukraine|Ukraine's National Bank]]. Outside government, Poroshenko has been a prominent [[Ukrainian oligarch]]{{cite web|title=Profile: Ukraine's President Petro Poroshenko|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-26822741|publisher=BBC|date=7 June 2014|accessdate=10 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140526215821/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-26822741|archivedate=26 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} with a lucrative career in acquiring and building assets. His most recognized brands are [[Roshen]], the large-scale confectionery company which has earned him the nickname of 'Chocolate King', and the TV channel ''[[5 kanal]]'', an all-news national TV broadcaster. Due to the scale of his business holdings in the manufacturing, agriculture and financial sectors, his political influence that included several stints at government prior to his presidency, and ownership of an influential mass-media outlet, Poroshenko has long been considered one of the prominent Ukrainian oligarchs even though not the most influential among them. He was [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|elected president on 25 May 2014]], capturing more than 54% of the vote in the first round, thereby winning outright and avoiding a run-off. ==Early life and education== Poroshenko was born in the city of [[Bolhrad]], in [[Odessa Oblast]], on 26 September 1965 to Oleksij Ivanovich Poroshenko and Evgenia Sergeevna (née Grigorchuk).{{cite web|url=http://www.therichest.com/celebnetworth/celebrity-business/men/petro-poroshenko-net-worth/ |title=Petro Poroshenko Net Worth |work=The Richest |accessdate=26 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822061718/http://www.therichest.com/celebnetworth/celebrity-business/men/petro-poroshenko-net-worth/ |archivedate=22 August 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/mobile/news/world/kerry-heads-for-crisis-talks-over-ukraine-1-3358208 |title=Kerry heads for crisis talks over Ukraine |work=[[The Scotsman]] |date=29 March 2014 |accessdate=26 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527174812/http://www.scotsman.com/mobile/news/world/kerry-heads-for-crisis-talks-over-ukraine-1-3358208 |archivedate=27 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} His father, {{Interlanguage link|Oleksij Poroshenko|de|Oleksij Poroschenko|uk|Порошенко Олексій Іванович|ru|Порошенко, Алексей Иванович|WD=}}, was an engineer and later government official who managed several factories during the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet rule in Ukraine]]. Little is known about his mother but a Ukrainian newspaper said she was an accountant, who taught at a vocational and technical school of accounting.{{cite web|url=https://vinbazar.com/news/nshe/mati-ta-starshii-brat-petra-porosa-trokhi-sa-na-nevidomi-storinki-biografiyi|title=Матір та старший брат Петра Порошенка - білі плями біографії майбутнього Президента|language=Ukrainian|date=5 June 2014|publisher=Vinbazar}} He also spent his childhood and youth in [[Bender, Moldova|Bendery]] ([[Moldavian SSR]], now under ''de facto'' control of the unrecognized [[List of states with limited recognition|breakaway state]] [[Transnistria]]).[https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/540626.html All In The Family: The Sequel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129115129/https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/540626.html |date=29 November 2016 }}, [[Kyiv Post]] (7 October 2016){{cite web|author=Marcin Kosienkowski|url=https://www.academia.edu/1918412/Continuity_and_Change_in_Transnistrias_Foreign_Policy_after_the_2011_Presidential_Elections|title=Continuity and Change in Transnistria's Foreign Policy after the 2011 Presidential Elections|publisher=[[Academia.edu]]|date=2012|page=38}} where his father Oleksij was heading a machine building plant. In his youth, Poroshenko practiced judo and [[Sambo (martial art)|sambo]], and was a [[Unified Sports Classification System of the USSR and Russia|Candidate for Master of Sport of the USSR]]. Despite good grades he was not awarded the normal gold medal at graduation, and on his report card he was given a "C" for his behavior. After getting into a fight with four [[Soviet Army]] cadets at the military commissariat, he was sent to army service in the distant [[Kazakh SSR]]. In 1989, Poroshenko graduated, having started studying in 1982, with a degree in economics from the international relations and law department (subsequently the Institute of International Relations) at the [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv|Kiev State University]].{{cite news|url=http://tass.ru/en/economy/733301 |title=Ukraine's tycoon Poroshenko confirms plans to sell assets |agency=[[Information Telegraph Agency of Russia|ITAR-TASS]] |date=26 May 2014 |accessdate=26 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527220635/http://en.itar-tass.com/economy/733301 |archivedate=27 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} At this university he was friends with [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] who he in May 2015 would appoint as [[Governor of Odessa Oblast|Governor]] of the [[Odessa Oblast]] (region) and who is a former [[President of Georgia]] .{{uk icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20150531021718/http://m.dw.de/ukrainian/mobile.A-18487589-9874.html Saakashvili took over as head of the Odessa Regional State Administration], [[Deutsche Welle]] (30 May 2015) In 1984 Poroshenko married a medical student, Maryna Perevedentseva (born 1962). Their first son, Oleksiy, was born in 1985 ([[Oleksiy Poroshenko|his three other children were born in 2000 and 2001]]). From 1989 to 1992 Poroshenko was an assistant at the university's international economic relations department. While still a student, he founded a legal advisory firm mediating the negotiation of contracts in foreign trade, and then he undertook the negotiations himself, starting to supply [[cocoa bean]]s to the Soviet chocolate industry in 1991. At the same time, he was deputy director of the 'Republic' Union of Small Businesses and Entrepreneurs, and the CEO "Exchange House Ukraine". Poroshenko's brother, Mykhailo, older by eight years, died in a 1997 car accident under mysterious circumstances.{{ru icon}}'''/(website has automatic [[Google Translate]] option)''' [http://file.liga.net/person/404-petr-poroshenko.html Short bio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305055205/http://file.liga.net/person/404-petr-poroshenko.html |date=5 March 2013 }}, LIGA ==Business career== In 1993, Poroshenko, together with his father Oleksiy and colleagues from the Road Traffic Institute in Kiev, created the UkrPromInvest Ukrainian Industry and Investment Company, which specialized in the confectionery and automotive industries (as well as in other agricultural processing later on.) Poroshenko was director-general of the company from its founding until 1998, when in connection with his entry into parliament he handed the title over to his father, while retaining the title of honorary president. Between 1996 and 1998, UkrPromInvest acquired control over several state-owned confectionery enterprises which were combined into the [[Roshen]] group in 1996, creating the largest confectionery manufacturing operation in [[Ukraine]]. His business success in this industry earned him the nickname "Chocolate King".{{cite news|author=Abram Brown |date=31 March 2014 |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/abrambrown/2014/03/31/the-willy-wonka-of-ukraine-is-now-the-leading-presidential-candidate/ |title=The Willy Wonka of Ukraine Is Now The Leading Presidential Candidate |journal=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=19 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201194141/http://www.forbes.com/sites/abrambrown/2014/03/31/the-willy-wonka-of-ukraine-is-now-the-leading-presidential-candidate/ |archivedate=1 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Poroshenko's business empire also includes several car and bus factories, [[Kuznya na Rybalskomu]] shipyard, the [[5 Kanal (Ukraine)|5 Kanal]] television channel,{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/67473/ |title=Poroshenko is not going to sell Channel 5 TV |work=Kyiv Post |date=23 May 2010 |accessdate=25 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100525042142/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/67473/ |archivedate=25 May 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} as well as other businesses in Ukraine. Although not the most prominent in the list of his business holdings, the assets that drew much recent media attention, and often controversy, are the confectionery factory in [[Lipetsk]], Russia, that became controversial due to the [[Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)]], the [[Sevastopol Marine Plant]] (Sevmorzavod) that has been confiscated after the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|2014 Russian forcible annexation of Crimea]] and the media outlet [[5 kanal]], particularly because of Poroshenko's repeated refusal to sell an influential media asset following his accession to presidency. According to Poroshenko (and [[N M Rothschild & Sons|Rothschild Wealth Management & Trust]]) since becoming President of Ukraine he has relinquished the management of his businesses, ultimately (in January 2016) to a [[blind trust]].[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/397675.html Roshen quits activity of its factory in Lipetsk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170120130300/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/397675.html |date=20 January 2017 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 January 2017) === Billionaires lists rankings=== In March 2012, ''[[Forbes]]'' placed him on the [[Forbes list of billionaires (2012)|Forbes list of billionaires]] at 1,153rd place, with $1 billion USD.{{cite news|date=8 March 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2012 |author=Brian Bonner |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/123875/ |title=Eight Ukrainians make Forbes magazine's list of world billionaires |newspaper=[[Kyiv Post]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201194141/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/123875/ |archivedate=1 December 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} As of May 2015, Poroshenko's net worth was about $720 million USD ([[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]] estimate), losing 25 percent of his wealth because of Russia's ban of Roshen products and the state of the Ukrainian economy.{{cite news|title=Billionaire No More: Ukraine President's Fortune Fades With War|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-08/billionaire-no-more-ukraine-president-s-fortune-fades-with-war|newspaper=Bloomberg Business|date=8 May 2015|accessdate=22 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526063035/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-08/billionaire-no-more-ukraine-president-s-fortune-fades-with-war|archivedate=26 May 2015|df=dmy-all}} According to the annual ranking of the richest people in Ukraine{{cite web|author=Vitaliy Sych|url=http://nv.ua/opinion/sych/poroshenko-rastet-ahmetov-padaet---svezhij-top-100-samyh-bogatyh-ukraintsev-77166.html|script-title=ru:Порошенко растет, Ахметов падает – свежий Топ-100 самых богатых украинцев|trans-title=Poroshenko grows, Akhmetov falls – Fresh Top 100 richest Ukrainians|language=ru|publisher=Novoe Vremia|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=10 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311074035/http://nv.ua/opinion/sych/poroshenko-rastet-ahmetov-padaet---svezhij-top-100-samyh-bogatyh-ukraintsev-77166.html|archivedate=11 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} published by the Ukrainian journal [[Novoye Vremya (journal and site)|Novoye Vremya]] and conducted jointly with [[Dragon Capital (Ukraine)|Dragon Capital]], a leading investment company in Ukraine, published in October 2015, president Poroshenko was found to be the only one from the top ten list whose asset value grew since the previous year's ranking. The estimate of his assets was set at $979 million USD, a 20% growth, and his ranking increased from 9th to 6th wealthiest person in Ukraine. The article noted that Poroshenko remained one of the only two European leaders who owned a business empire of such scale, with [[Silvio Berlusconi]] of Italy being the other. A total of €450 million is kept in an Amsterdam-based company registered in Cyprus, as a result of which his effective tax rate is 5% rather than the statutory tax rate of 18% in Ukraine. The company is likely to be worth much more, as the annual accounts published by the Dutch Chamber of Commerce only contain the book value of the shares, which is very likely to be lower than the market value.{{cite news|title=Alle schimmige geldstromen belastingontwijkende President Oekraïne in één handig overzicht|url=http://925.nl/archief/2016/11/24/handig-alle-schimmige-geldstromen-belastingontwijkende-president-oekraine-in-een-overzicht/|date=24 November 2016|accessdate=9 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415135655/http://925.nl/archief/2016/11/24/handig-alle-schimmige-geldstromen-belastingontwijkende-president-oekraine-in-een-overzicht/|archivedate=15 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} ===Associated businesses=== A number of businesses were once part of the {{ill|Ukrprominvest|uk|Група «Укрпромінвест»|vertical-align=sup}} which Poroshenko headed in 1993–1998. The investment group was dissolved in April 2012.{{cite news|url=http://economics.unian.ua/industry/640677-kontsern-ukrprominvest-ogolosiv-pro-likvidatsiyu.html |script-title=uk:Концерн "Укрпромінвест" оголосив про ліквідацію |trans-title=Concern "Ukrprominvest" announced its liquidation |agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] |date=24 April 2012 |accessdate=26 May 2014 |deadurl=no |archivedate=1 December 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201194141/http://economics.unian.ua/industry/640677-kontsern-ukrprominvest-ogolosiv-pro-likvidatsiyu.html |language=uk |df=dmy }} Poroshenko has stated that upon beginning his political activity he passed on his holdings to a trust fund. *[[Bogdan group]] (Poroshenko sold his share in connection with the collapse of its production after the [[2008 economic crisis]] in 2009), centered in [[Cherkasy]] *[[Roshen]] group *[[5 Kanal (Ukraine)|5 Kanal]] television channel *[[Kuznya na Rybalskomu]] shipyard in [[Kiev]] *International Invest Bank,Komakha, O. [https://web.archive.org/web/20171130021907/http://minprom.ua/articles/167144.html "The Poroshenko's Bank is growing in 10 times faster (Банк Порошенко растет в 10 раз быстрее)"]. Minprom Information Agency. 16 October 2014 owned through a trust and along with [[Ihor Kononenko]] *Ukrprominvest-Agro, an agrarian holding **[[Zorya Podillya]], an agrarian company near [[Haisyn]], specializing in sugar production from [[sugar beet]]s **Podillya **MAS-Agro **Ahrofirma "Dniproahrolan" **Ahrofirma "Ivankivtsi" * [[Sevastopol Shipyard]] (lost in 2015 due to a [[corporate raid]] by the Russian occupational authorities in Crimea) ==Early political career== Poroshenko first won a seat in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (the Ukrainian Parliament) [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1998|in 1998]] for the [[Vinnytsia II (single-mandate constituency)|12th single-mandate constituency]]. He was initially a member of the [[United Social Democratic Party of Ukraine]] (SDPU), the party led by [[Viktor Medvedchuk]] and loyal to president [[Leonid Kuchma]] at the time. Poroshenko left SDPU(o) in 2000 to create an independent [[Left-wing politics|left]]-of-[[Centrism|center]] faction and then a party, naming it [[Solidarity (Ukraine)|Party of Ukraine's Solidarity]] (PSU).{{cite web|format=PDF|author-link1=Taras Kuzio|author1=Kuzio, Taras|author2=Frishberg, Alex|url=http://www.taraskuzio.net/legal_files/Frishberg_Feb.08.pdf|title=Ukrainian Political Update|date=21 February 2008|work=Frishberg & Partners, Attorneys at Law|page=22|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303173602/http://www.taraskuzio.net/legal_files/Frishberg_Feb.08.pdf|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} In 2001 Poroshenko was instrumental in creating the [[Party of Regions]], also loyal to Kuchma; the Party of Ukraine's Solidarity having merged into the Party of Regions, Poroshenko launched a new party with a similar name, the party "[[Solidarity (Ukraine)|Solidarity]]. ==Secretary of the National Security and Defense Council== [[File:Mukacheve 2004 Yushchenko and Baloha.JPG|thumb|left|Poroshenko and [[Viktor Yushchenko]] during the meeting before [[Mukacheve]] mayoral election on 16 April 2004.]] In December 2001 Poroshenko broke ranks with Kuchma supporters to become campaign chief of [[Viktor Yushchenko]]'s [[Our Ukraine Bloc]] opposition faction. After [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2002|parliamentary elections in March 2002]] in which Our Ukraine won the biggest share of the popular vote and Poroshenko won a seat in parliament,{{cite news|accessdate=23 June 2010|url=http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vd2002/webproc0e|title=Results of voting in single-mandate constituencies|publisher=[[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]}}{{Dead link|date=March 2016}}{{cbignore}} Poroshenko served as head of the parliamentary budget committee, where he was accused of "misplacing 47 million hryvnias" (USD$8.9 million).{{cite book|author=Freedom House|title=Nations in Transit 2004: Democratization in East Central Europe and Eurasia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AsJlnVU4ipoC&pg=PA638|date=2004|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4617-3141-2|pages=638–|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113164920/https://books.google.com/books?id=AsJlnVU4ipoC&pg=PA638|archivedate=13 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} As a consequence of Poroshenko's Our Ukraine Bloc membership tax inspectors launched an attack on his business. Despite great difficulties, UkrPromInvest managed to survive until Yushchenko became [[President of Ukraine]] in 2005. Poroshenko was considered a close confidant of Yushchenko, who is the godfather of Poroshenko's daughters. Poroshenko was likely the wealthiest oligarch among Yushchenko supporters, and was often named as one of the main financial backers of Our Ukraine and the [[Orange Revolution]].{{cite web|date=25 May 2014 |accessdate=26 May 2014 |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/politics/op-ed-petro-poroshenko-the-oligarch-poised-to-become-ukraine-president/article/384617 |title=Op-Ed: Petro Poroshenko the oligarch poised to become Ukraine president |work=Digital Journal |last=Hanly |first=Ken |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527181527/http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/politics/op-ed-petro-poroshenko-the-oligarch-poised-to-become-ukraine-president/article/384617 |archivedate=27 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} After Yushchenko won the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|presidential elections in 2004]], Poroshenko was appointed Secretary of the [[National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine|National Security and Defense Council]]. [[File:Petro Poroshenko (2005 ).jpg|thumb|Poroshenko attending a U.S. Independence Day celebration at the [[Embassy of the United States, Kiev|U.S. Embassy in Kiev]], 6 July 2005.]] In September 2005, highly publicized mutual allegations of corruption erupted between Poroshenko and Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] involving the privatizations of state-owned firms. Poroshenko, for example, was accused of defending the interests of [[Viktor Pinchuk]], who had acquired state firm Nikopol Ferroalloy for $80 million, independently valued at $1 billion.{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-09-27/news/0509270090_1_petro-poroshenko-privatization-ukrainians |title=In Ukraine, old whiff of scandal in new regime |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=27 September 2005 |author=Alex Rodriguez |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002143944/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-09-27/news/0509270090_1_petro-poroshenko-privatization-Ukrainians |archivedate=2 October 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In response to the allegations, Yushchenko dismissed his entire [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|cabinet of ministers]], including Poroshenko and Tymoshenko.{{cite news |url=http://files.korrespondent.net/persons/poroshenko |language=ru |title=Biography |publisher=[[Korrespondent.net]] |deadurl=yes |archivedate=19 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719091220/http://files.korrespondent.net/politics/poroshenko/ |df=dmy }} State prosecutors dismissed an abuse of power investigation against Poroshenko the following month,{{cite news|title=Prosecutors Close Criminal Case Against Yushchenko's Close Ally|url=http://news.kievukraine.info/2005/10/prosecutors-close-criminal-case.html|date=21 October 2005|publisher=Kiev Ukraine News Blog|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407082558/http://news.kievukraine.info/2005/10/prosecutors-close-criminal-case.html|archivedate=7 April 2014|df=dmy-all}} immediately after Yushchenko dismissed [[Svyatoslav Piskun]], [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine]]. Piskun claimed that he was sacked because he refused to institute criminal proceedings against Tymoshenko and refused to drop proceedings against Poroshenko.{{cite web |date=28 October 2005 |accessdate=3 March 2012 |url=http://en.for-ua.com/analytics/2005/10/28/164030.html |title=Independent standpoint on Ukraine:Dismissal of Prosecutor-General, Closure of Poroshenko Case Create New |author=Tammy M. Lynch |publisher=ForUm |archivedate=3 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103105813/http://en.for-ua.com/analytics/2005/10/28/164030.html |df=dmy }} In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|March 2006 parliamentary election]] Poroshenko was re-elected to the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]] with the support of [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine]] electoral bloc. He chaired the parliamentary Committee on Finance and Banking. Allegedly, since Poroshenko claimed the post of [[Chairman of the Ukrainian Parliament]] for himself, the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] chose to be part of the [[Alliance of National Unity]] because it was promised that their party leader, [[Oleksandr Moroz]], would be elected chairman if the coalition were formed. This left Poroshenko's Our Ukraine and their ally [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]] out of the [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|Government]]. Poroshenko did not run in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|September 2007 parliamentary election]]. Poroshenko started heading the Council of [[National Bank of Ukraine|Ukraine's National Bank]] in February 2007.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/50277/ |title=Regions Party not to vote for Poroshenko's appointment Ukraine's foreign minister |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date=8 October 2009 |accessdate=8 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=5 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605175033/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/50277/ |df=dmy }} Between 1999 and 2012 he was a board member of the National Bank of Ukraine. ==Foreign Minister and Minister of Trade== [[File:Yulia Tymoshenko November 2009-4.jpeg|thumb|Poroshenko at the Russian-Ukrainian international commission meeting in 2009.]] [[File:George Papandreou and Petro Poroshenko 2009.jpg|left|thumb|Minister for Foreign Affairs of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko in the Polish Senate with former Greek prime minister [[George Papandreou]].]] Ukrainian President [[Yushchenko]] nominated Poroshenko for [[Foreign Minister of Ukraine|Foreign Minister]] on 7 October 2009.{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/21575.html|title=Ukrainian president proposes Petro Poroshenko for foreign minister|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=7 October 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311072531/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/21575.html|archivedate=11 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} Poroshenko was appointed by the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's parliament) on 9 October 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/21692/ |title=Rada appoints Poroshenko Ukraine's foreign minister |agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date=9 October 2009 |accessdate=5 December 2009 |archivedate=23 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523175756/http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/21575/ |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}By 240 out of 440 MPs registered in the session hall. In particular, 151 MPs of the [[Bloc of Yulia Tymoshenko]] faction, 63 of the [[Our Ukraine-People's Self-Defense Bloc]], 20 members of the [[Bloc of Volodymyr Lytvyn]], one deputy of the [[Party of Regions]], one member of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist Party]] faction, and four deputies not belonging to any faction voted for the nomination. On 12 October 2009, President Yushchenko re-appointed Poroshenko to the National Security and Defense Council.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/poroshenko-put-on-ukraines-nscd-50528.html |title=Poroshenko put on Ukraine's NSCD |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=12 October 2009 |deadurl=no |archivedate=19 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419153310/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/poroshenko-put-on-ukraines-nscd-50528.html |df=dmy }} Poroshenko supported [[NATO-Ukrainian relations|Ukrainian NATO-membership]]. However, he also stated [[Enlargement of NATO|NATO membership]] should not be a goal in itself.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54359/ |title=Poroshenko: Ukraine could join NATO in 1–2 years, with political, public will |work=Kyiv Post |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=4 December 2009 |accessdate=5 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110130215152/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54359/ |archivedate=30 January 2011 |df=dmy }} Although Poroshenko was dismissed as foreign minister on 11 March 2010, President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] expressed hope for further cooperation with him. In late February 2012 Poroshenko was named as the new [[Ministry of Economic Development and Trade (Ukraine)|Minister of Trade and Economic Development]] in the [[Azarov Government]];{{cite news|date=23 February 2012 |accessdate=9 March 2012 |url=http://www.unian.info/politics/612959-mass-media-poroshenko-heads-ministry-of-economy.html |title=Mass Media:Poroshenko heads Ministry of Economy |agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] |archivedate=24 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224153502/http://www.unian.net/eng/news/487680-mass-media-poroshenko-heads-ministry-of-economy.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|date=23 February 2012 |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/122996/ |title=Regions Party: Poroshenko appointed economy minister, Kolobov appointed finance minister |work=Kyiv Post |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |accessdate=9 March 2012 |archivedate=9 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309085122/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/122996/ |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/23085.html |title=President:Prime Minister nominated Petro Poroshenko for Minister of Economy |publisher=[[President.gov.ua]] |date=23 February 2012 |accessdate=3 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140128000855/http://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/23085.html |archivedate=28 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} on 9 March 2012 President Yanukovych stated he wanted Poroshenko to work in the government in the post of economic development and trade minister.{{cite news|date=9 March 2012 |accessdate=9 March 2012 |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/123980/ |title=Ukrainian president wants Poroshenko to head economic development and trade ministry |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309162724/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/123980/ |archivedate=9 March 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 23 March 2012 Poroshenko was appointed economic development and trade minister of Ukraine by Yanukovych.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/124833/ |title=Poroshenko appointed economic development and trade minister of Ukraine|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|accessdate=23 March 2012|date=23 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201194141/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/124833/|archivedate=1 December 2008}}
{{cite news|date=23 March 2012|accessdate=23 March 2012|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/124844/|title=Poroshenko explains reasons behind accepting economy minister's post|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|archivedate=23 March 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323190901/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/124844/}} The same month he stepped down as head of the Council of [[National Bank of Ukraine|Ukraine's National Bank]].{{cite web|publisher=LIGA.net |url=http://file.liga.net/person/404-petr-poroshenko.html |script-title=ru:Порошенко Петр Алексеевич |trans-title=Petr Aleksiyovych Poroshenko |accessdate=20 February 2013 |archivedate=5 March 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305055205/http://file.liga.net/person/404-petr-poroshenko.html |language=ru |df=dmy }} Poroshenko claims that he became Minister of Trade and Economic Development in order to help bring [[Ukraine–European Union relations|Ukraine closer to the EU]] and get Yulia Tymoshenko [[Criminal cases against Yulia Tymoshenko since 2010|released from prison]]. After he took the post, tax inspectors launched an attack on his business. ==Return to parliament== Poroshenko returned to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) after the [[2012 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] after winning (with more than 70%) as an independent candidate in [[single-member districts|single-member district]] number 12 ([[first-past-the-post]] wins a parliamentary seat) located in [[Vinnytsia Oblast]].{{uk icon}} [http://www.rbc.ua/rus/vyboru2012/person/o101 Candidates single-mandate constituency № 12] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605053136/http://www.rbc.ua/rus/vyboru2012/person/o101 |date=5 June 2014 }}, [[RBC Ukraine]]{{cite web|url=http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/WP040?PT001F01=900&pf7331=12|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221141512/http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/WP040?PT001F01=900&pf7331=12|archivedate=21 February 2014|script-title=uk:Полтавська область. Одномандатний виборчий округ №112|trans-title=Vinnytsia region. The single-mandate constituency № 12|publisher=[[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]|language=uk|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|accessdate=14 December 2012 |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/minister-poroshenko-and-his-father-registered-as-self-nominees-for-districts-in-vinnytsia-region-311570.html |title=Minister Poroshenko and his father registered as self-nominees for Vinnytsia region |work=Kyiv Post |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=15 August 2012 |deadurl=no |archivedate=20 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121220053732/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/minister-poroshenko-and-his-father-registered-as-self-nominees-for-districts-in-vinnytsia-region-311570.html |df=dmy }} He did not enter any faction in parliament{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/poroshenko-not-intending-to-join-any-faction-317539.html |title=Poroshenko not intending to join any faction |work=[[Kyiv Post]] |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=12 December 2012 |accessdate=14 December 2012 |deadurl=no |archivedate=14 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121214133925/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/poroshenko-not-intending-to-join-any-faction-317539.html |df=dmy }}
{{cite news|date=20 June 2013 |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/poroshenko-fears-uncontrolled-economic-situation-in-ukraine-due-to-foreign-borrowing-325913.html |title=Poroshenko fears uncontrolled economic situation in Ukraine due to foreign borrowing |agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |work=Kyiv Post |accessdate=20 June 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923233703/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/poroshenko-fears-uncontrolled-economic-situation-in-ukraine-due-to-foreign-borrowing-325913.html |archivedate=23 September 2013 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} and became member of the [[Committee of the Verkhovna Rada on issues of European integration|committee on European Integration]]. Poroshenko's father Oleksiy did intend to take part in the elections too in single-member district number 16 (also located in Vinnytsia Oblast), but withdrew his candidacy for health reasons.{{uk icon}} [http://www.rbc.ua/rus/vyboru2012/person/o105 Candidates single-mandate constituency № 16], [[RBC Ukraine]]{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/politics/697310-poroshenkos-father-changes-his-mind-to-withdraw-his-candidacy-from-elections.html |title=Poroshenko's father changes his mind to withdraw his candidacy from elections |agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] |date=25 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904162445/http://www.unian.info/politics/697310-poroshenkos-father-changes-his-mind-to-withdraw-his-candidacy-from-elections.html |archivedate=4 September 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In mid-February 2013, Poroshenko hinted he would run for [[Mayor of Kiev]] in the [[Kiev mayoral election, 2013|2013 Kiev mayoral election]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ukrainebusiness.com.ua/news/8734.html |title=Poroshenko appears set to join race for Kyiv mayor |publisher=Ukraine Business Online |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=15 February 2013 |archivedate=19 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419005026/http://www.ukrainebusiness.com.ua/news/8734.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In 2013 the registration certificate of Solidarity was cancelled because for more than 10 years had not participated in any election. Poroshenko then launched and became leader of the [[National Alliance of freedom and Ukrainian patriotism "OFFENSIVE"]] (NASTUP), which was renamed "All-Ukrainian Union Solidarity" (BOS). ===2014 Ukrainian revolt=== [[File:Secretary Kerry Poses for a Photo With Ukranian Opposition Leaders in Munich.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian opposition leaders [[Vitali Klitschko]], Poroshenko (second left) and [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]] (right) with [[United States Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] (second right) at the [[Munich Security Conference]], 2014.]] {{main|2014 Ukrainian revolution}} During the [[Euromaidan]] protests, between November 2013 and February 2014, Poroshenko actively supported the protest, including with financial support. This led to an upsurge of his popularity. He did not participate in negotiations between then President Yanukovych and the Euromaidan parliamentary opposition parties [[Batkivshchyna]], [[Svoboda (party)|Svoboda]] and [[UDAR]]. In an interview with [[Lally Weymouth]], Poroshenko said: "From the beginning, I was one of the organizers of the Maidan. My television channel — Channel 5 — played a tremendously important role. ... At that time, Channel 5 started to broadcast, there were just 2,000 people on the Maidan. But during the night, people went by foot — seven, eight, nine, 10 kilometers — understanding this is a fight for Ukrainian freedom and democracy. In four hours, almost 30,000 people were there."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interview-with-ukrainian-presidential-candidate-petro-poroshenko/2014/04/25/74c73a48-cbbd-11e3-93eb-6c0037dde2ad_story.html|title=Interview with Ukrainian presidential candidate Petro Poroshenko|date=25 April 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140604095721/http://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/interview-with-ukrainian-presidential-candidate-petro-poroshenko/2014/04/25/74c73a48-cbbd-11e3-93eb-6c0037dde2ad_story.html|archivedate=4 June 2014|df=dmy-all}} The [[BBC]] reported, "Mr Poroshenko owns 5 Kanal TV, the most popular news channel in Ukraine, which showed clear pro-opposition sympathies during the months of political crisis in Kiev." Poroshenko refused to join the [[First Yatsenyuk Government|Yatsenyuk Government]] (although he introduced his colleague [[Volodymyr Groysman]], the mayor of [[Vinnytsia]], into it), nor did he join any of the two newly created parliamentary factions [[Economic Development (parliamentary faction)|Economic Development]] and [[Sovereign European Ukraine]]. On 24 April 2014 Poroshenko visited [[Luhansk]], at the time [[Luhansk People's Republic#Occupation of government buildings|not controlled by Ukrainian authorities]]. Just like previously in Crimea he was met by a blockade of hundreds of [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian locals]] at [[Luhansk Airport]]. Poroshenko later claimed: "When I traveled to [[Luhansk Oblast]], my car was fired at and there was an attempt to take our entire group hostage." ===2014 presidential campaign=== [[File:Poroshenko-2014-en.png|thumb|2014 presidential election percentage of vote for Poroshenko.]] {{main|Ukrainian presidential election, 2014}} Following the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution]] and the resulting removal of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from the office of President of Ukraine, new presidential elections were scheduled to take place on 25 May 2014.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-26312008 |title=Ukraine: Speaker Oleksandr Turchynov named interim president |publisher=BBC News |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=29 March 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327024822/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-26312008 |archivedate=27 March 2014 |df=dmy }}
{{cite news|date=23 February 2014 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26248275 |title=Ukraine protests timeline |publisher=BBC News |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201194141/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26248275 |archivedate=19 February 2014 |deadurl=no |accessdate=29 March 2014 |df=dmy }} In pre-election polls from March 2014, Poroshenko garnered the most support of all the prospective candidates, with one poll conducted by SOCIS giving him a rating of over 40%.[http://www.socis.kiev.ua/ Главная | Центр соціальних та маркетингових досліджень SOCIS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521070707/http://socis.kiev.ua/ |date=21 May 2014 }}. Socis.kiev.ua. Retrieved 28 May 2014. On 29 March he stated that he would run for president; at the same time [[Vitali Klitschko]] left the presidential contest, choosing to support Poroshenko's bid.{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198350.html |title=Klitschko will run for mayor of Kyiv |accessdate=29 March 2014 |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=29 March 2014 |archivedate=30 March 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330005126/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198350.html |df=dmy }}{{cite news|agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=29 March 2014 |accessdate=29 March 2014 |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198348.html |title=Klitschko believes only presidential candidate from democratic forces should be Poroshenko |deadurl=no |archivedate=11 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011034026/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198348.html |df=dmy }}{{cite news|date=29 March 2014 |accessdate=29 March 2014 |author=Colin Freeman |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10731848/Petro-Poroshenko-the-billionaire-chocolate-baron-hoping-to-become-Ukraines-next-president.html |title=Petro Poroshenko, the billionaire chocolate baron hoping to become Ukraine's next president |work=The Daily Telegraph |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330003104/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10731848/Petro-Poroshenko-the-billionaire-chocolate-baron-hoping-to-become-Ukraines-next-president.html |deadurl=no |archivedate=30 March 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=http://www.euronews.com/2014/03/29/ukraine-former-boxer-vitaliy-klitschko-ends-presidential-bid-and-backs-/ |title=Ukraine: former boxer Vitaliy Klitschko ends presidential bid and backs Poroshenko |publisher=[[Euronews]] |date=29 March 2014 |archivedate=30 March 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330021851/http://www.euronews.com/2014/03/29/ukraine-former-boxer-vitaliy-klitschko-ends-presidential-bid-and-backs-/ |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 2 April Poroshenko stated, "If I am elected, I will be honest and sell the Roshen Concern."{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/198849.html |title=Poroshenko ready to sell Roshen if elected president |agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=2 April 2014 |accessdate=2 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407080918/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/198849.html |archivedate=7 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} He also said in early April that the level of popular support for the idea of [[Ukraine–NATO relations|Ukraine's joining NATO]] was too small to put on the agenda "so as not to ruin the country."{{cite news|agency=Interfax-Ukraine |date=2 April 2014 |accessdate=2 April 2014 |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198839.html |title=Question of Ukraine's membership of NATO may split country – Poroshenko |archivedate=7 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407080915/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/198839.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} He also vowed not to sell his [[5 Kanal (Ukraine)|5 Kanal]] television channel.{{cite news|date=25 May 2014|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304811904579583413180447156|title=Poroshenko Declares Victory in Ukraine Presidential Election|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=29 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528033721/http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304811904579583413180447156|archivedate=28 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} On 14 April, Poroshenko publicly endorsed the campaign of [[Jarosław Gowin]]'s party [[Poland Together]] of neighboring Poland in this year's elections to the European Parliament, thanking Gowin's party colleague [[Paweł Kowal]] for supporting Ukraine.{{cite news |accessdate=14 April 2014 |url=http://www.polskieradio.pl/5/3/Artykul/1098445,Polska-Razem-czarnym-koniem-Mocne-slowa-Gowina |title=Polska Razem czarnym koniem? Mocne słowa Gowina |trans-title=Polish Total black horse? Strong words Gowin |date=12 April 2014 |language=pl |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415025816/http://www.polskieradio.pl/5/3/Artykul/1098445%2CPolska-Razem-czarnym-koniem-Mocne-slowa-Gowina |archivedate=15 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Poroshenko's election slogan was: "Live in a new way – Poroshenko!".{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/profile-of-petro-poroshenko-in-the-run-up-to-the-ukraine-elections-a-970325.html |title=Ukraine Election: The Chocolate King Rises |publisher=[[Spiegel Online]] |date=22 May 2014 |deadurl=no |archivedate=28 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528051631/http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/profile-of-petro-poroshenko-in-the-run-up-to-the-ukraine-elections-a-970325.html |df=dmy }} On 29 May, the [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]] announced that Poroshenko had won 25 May presidential election, with 54.7% of the votes.{{cite news|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date=29 May 2014 |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/207146.html |title=Poroshenko wins presidential election with 54.7% of vote – CEC |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529201857/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/207146.html |archivedate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/ukraine-talks-set-to-open-without-pro-russian-separatists/2014/05/14/621dbc6a-c7d9-40bc-b2e5-814a4108bbef_story.html|title=Ukraine talks set to open without pro-Russian separatists|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=14 May 2014|accessdate=29 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528213228/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/ukraine-talks-set-to-open-without-pro-russian-separatists/2014/05/14/621dbc6a-c7d9-40bc-b2e5-814a4108bbef_story.html|archivedate=28 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|date=22 May 2014 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989 |title=Ukraine elections: Runners and risks |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=29 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527092109/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989 |archivedate=27 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8460978.stm |title=Q&A: Ukraine presidential election |publisher=BBC News |date=7 February 2010 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=no |archivedate=29 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429045939/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8460978.stm |df=dmy }}{{cite web|publisher=[[Radio Ukraine International]] |accessdate=29 May 2014 |url=http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |title=Poroshenko wins presidential election with 54.7% of vote – CEC |date=29 May 2014 |archivedate=29 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529212731/http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}
{{cite news|publisher=Телеграф |url=http://telegraf.com.ua/ukraina/politika/1300294-rezultatyi-vyiborov-prezidenta-ukrainyi-2014-tsik-obrabotala-51-99.html |script-title=ru:Внеочередные выборы Президента Украины |trans-title=Results election of Ukrainian president |date=29 May 2014 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |language=ru |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529233925/http://telegraf.com.ua/ukraina/politika/1300294-rezultatyi-vyiborov-prezidenta-ukrainyi-2014-tsik-obrabotala-51-99.html |archivedate=29 May 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/205114.html |title=New Ukrainian president will be elected for 5-year term – Constitutional Court |date=16 May 2014 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517121006/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/205114.html |archivedate=17 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} During his visit in [[Berlin]], Poroshenko stated that separatists "don't represent anybody. We have to restore law and order and sweep the terrorists off the street."{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/poroshenko-no-negotiations-with-separatists/a-17619764 |title=Poroshenko: 'No negotiations with separatists' |publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=8 May 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524124039/http://www.dw.de/poroshenko-no-negotiations-with-separatists/a-17619764 |archivedate=24 May 2014 |df=dmy }} He described as "fake" a planned 11 May [[Donbass status referendums, 2014|Donbass status referendums]]. ==Presidency== [[File:Donald Tusk and Poroshenko.jpg|thumb|[[President of Ukraine]] Petro Poroshenko and President of European Council [[Donald Tusk]] in Brussels, 2015.]] When it became clear he had won the election on election day evening (on 25 May 2014) Poroshenko announced "My first presidential trip will be to [[Donbas]]", where [[2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine|armed pro-Russian rebels]] had declared the separatist republics [[Donetsk People's Republic]] and [[Lugansk People's Republic]] and control a large part of the region.{{cite news|title=Ukraine crisis timeline |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26248275 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530112656/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26248275 |archivedate=30 May 2014 |df=dmy }} Poroshenko also vowed to continue the military operations by the Ukrainian government forces to end the armed insurgency claiming "The anti-terrorist operation cannot and should not last two or three months. It should and will last hours."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/26/poroshenko-peace-donetsk-airport-air-strike-separatists |title=Poroshenko promises calm 'in hours' amid battle to control Donetsk airport |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=26 May 2014 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529072943/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/26/poroshenko-peace-donetsk-airport-air-strike-separatists |archivedate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} He compared the armed pro-Russian rebels to [[Somali pirates]]. Poroshenko also called for negotiations with Russia in the presence of international intermediaries. Russia responded by saying it did not need an intermediary in its bilateral relations with Ukraine. As president-elect Poroshenko promised to return Crimea, which [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|was annexed by Russia]] in March 2014.{{cite web|url=http://eeas.europa.eu/statements/docs/2014/140417_03_en.pdf |title=EU & Ukraine 17 April 2014 FACT SHEET |publisher=[[European External Action Service]] |format=PDF |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514174415/http://eeas.europa.eu/statements/docs/2014/140417_03_en.pdf |archivedate=14 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}{{efn|The status of the Crimea and of the city of [[Sevastopol]] is currently [[2014 Crimean crisis|under dispute between Russia and Ukraine]]; Ukraine and the majority of the international community consider the Crimea to be an [[autonomous republic]] of Ukraine and Sevastopol to be one of Ukraine's [[cities with special status]], while Russia, on the other hand, considers the Crimea to be a [[federal subject of Russia]] and Sevastopol to be one of Russia's three [[federal cities of Russia|federal cities]].{{cite news|last1=Gutterman |first1=Steve |last2=Polityuk |first2=Pavel |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/18/us-ukraine-crisis-idUSBREA1Q1E820140318 |title=Putin signs Crimea treaty, will not seize other Ukraine regions |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=18 March 2014 |accessdate=26 March 2014 |archivedate=29 March 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140329012404/https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/18/us-ukraine-crisis-idUSBREA1Q1E820140318 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}}} He also vowed to hold new [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|parliamentary elections in 2014]].{{cite news|date=25 May 2014|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/ukrainians-head-to-the-polls-to-elect-a-new-president-except-in-the-restive-east/2014/05/25/2680fad4-e9f7-4118-923e-852b01351b39_story.html|title=In Ukrainian election, chocolate tycoon Poroshenko claims victory|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904072819/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/ukrainians-head-to-the-polls-to-elect-a-new-president-except-in-the-restive-east/2014/05/25/2680fad4-e9f7-4118-923e-852b01351b39_story.html|archivedate=4 September 2014|df=dmy-all}} ===Inauguration=== Poroshenko was inaugurated in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (parliament) on 7 June 2014.{{cite news|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20140529-707812.html|title=Petro Poroshenko to Be Inaugurated as Ukraine President June 7|author=Lukas Alpert|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=29 May 2014|accessdate=29 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529234158/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20140529-707812.html |archivedate=29 May 2014}}
{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/207670.html|title=Rada decides to hold inauguration of Poroshenko on June 7 at 1000|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=3 June 2014|accessdate=3 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140603165249/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/207670.html|archivedate=3 June 2014}}
{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/208367.html|title=Poroshenko sworn in as Ukrainian president|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=7 June 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=7 June 2014|archivedate=1 July 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701184604/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/208367.html}} In his inaugural address he stressed that [[2014 Crimean crisis|Ukraine would not give up Crimea]] and stressed the unity of Ukraine. He promised an amnesty "for those who do not have blood on their hands" to the separatist and [[Russophilia|pro-Russia]] insurgents of the [[2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine]] and to the [[Ukrainian nationalist]] groups that oppose them, but added: "Talking to gangsters and killers is not our path". He also called for early regional elections in [[Eastern Ukraine]]. Poroshenko also stated that he would sign the economic part of the [[Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement]] and that this was the first step towards full [[Ukrainian EU Membership]]. During the speech he stated he saw "[[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] as the only state language" but also spoke of the "guarantees [of] the unhindered development of Russian and all [[Languages of Ukraine|the other languages]]". Part of the speech was in Russian.{{cite news |publisher=[[theguardian.com]] |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=7 June 2014 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/07/ukraine-president-poroshenko-crimea-putin |title=Ukraine president vows not to give up Crimea |deadurl=no |archivedate=13 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140613194756/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/07/ukraine-president-poroshenko-crimea-putin |df=dmy }}
{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27745278 |title=Ukraine's Poroshenko sworn in and sets out peace plan |publisher=BBC News |date=7 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140609033038/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27745278 |archivedate=9 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}
{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27746994 |title=Excerpts from Poroshenko's speech |publisher=BBC News Online |date=7 June 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140608013854/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27746994 |archivedate=8 June 2014 |deadurl=no }}
